p:
There are over 500 arthropod-borne viruses worldwide, although not all cause human disease. The majority are usually restricted to specific geographic locations; for example, Ross River virus in Australia. However, due to a combination of international travel and changes in vector distribution there have been changes in the distribution of many arboviruses. They have short incubation periods (<1 week) and result in self-limiting illnesses. Four clinical presentations predominate:
•
Systemic febrile illness (e.g., all arboviruses)
•
Hemorrhagic fever (e.g., dengue, yellow fever, Rift Valley fever, Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever)
•
Acute encephalitis (e.g., Japanese encephalitis, Rift Valley fever, West Nile virus, Eastern and Western equine encephalitis viruses)
•
Polyarthralgia or arthritis (e.g., chikungunya, Ross River)
